name: Head Bandaging
description: Triangular bandage technique for head wounds
warning: For head wounds with bleeding. Apply pressure first to control bleeding.
emergency_notes: Do not remove objects embedded in wound
Monitor for signs of head injury

steps.title: Triangular Bandage
steps.description: You need a triangular bandage for this. You can also use cloth, clothes, or handkerchief as long as it is clean. Just cut or fold the alternative just like the triangular bandage.
steps.voice_prompt: Prepare a triangular bandage or a clean cloth alternative.

steps.title: Head Bandaging
steps.description: Fold the base of the triangular bandage once.
steps.voice_prompt: Fold the base of the triangular bandage once.

steps.title: Cover the Head
steps.description: Make sure to cover all of the backside of the head.
steps.voice_prompt: Place the bandage to cover the entire backside of the head.

steps.title: Secure the Bandaging
steps.description: To secure the bandage, wrap around the two edges into the front.
steps.voice_prompt: Wrap the two edges of the bandage around to the front.

steps.title: Square Knot
steps.description: Use the square knot to tie the bandage securely.
steps.voice_prompt: Begin tying a square knot with the two ends.
steps.critical_warning: Tip: To perform a square knot, hold the ends with each hand, put the right end over the left and tie, then put the left end over the right and tie

steps.title: Finish the Square Knot
steps.description: Complete the square knot to finish securing the bandage.
steps.voice_prompt: Finish tying the square knot securely.

steps.title: Why Use the Square Knot
steps.description: The very reason why we recommend the square knot is because it is secure while also being easy to untie.
steps.voice_prompt: The square knot is secure and easy to untie when needed.
steps.critical_warning: Tip: Square knots provide secure hold without slipping, yet can be quickly released in emergencies
